trial_identification.studytitle: Evaluation of Stenotrophomonas maltophilia case contamination and corneal infiltrative event rates in both experienced and new contact lens wearers.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Prospective, open-label, daily wear study of NIGHT & DAY[Registered trade mark] contact lenses in conjunction with OPTI-FREE[Registered trade mark] RepleniSH[Registered trade mark] lens care product to evaluate Stenotrophomonas maltophilia case contamination and corneal infiltrative event rates in both experienced and new contact lens wearers.

interventions.interventions: This is a prospective, single group, daily wear (DW) study where 90 participants will wear NIGHT & DAY [Registered trade mark] lenses bilaterally on a daily wear (DW) basis in conjunction with OPT-FREE [Trade mark] RepleniSH [Trade mark] solution for 4 months. There will be a minimum of 5 scheduled visits: baseline, 1 month visit, 2 month visit, 3 month visit and 4 month visit. These visits will involve assessment of visual acuity and examination with a slit-lamp biomicroscope (a specialised microscope for viewing the eye). Lenses will be worn a minimum of 5 days per week, and 6 hours on the day lenses are worn.
interventions.comparator: Correlation between contamination of contact lens cases with Stenotrophomonas maltophilia and corneal infiltrative events (CIEs)

primaryOutcome.outcome: To determine whether a correlation exists between contamination of contact lens cases with Stenotrophomonas maltophilia and CIEs, when contact lenses and worn on a daily wear basis.

trial_design.concealment: Particicpant needs to satisfy inclusion/exclusion criteria. All participants are allocated the same treatment

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: 1700 East St. Andrew Place PO Box 25162 Santa Ana, CA 92799-5162, USA

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Level 5, Rupert Myers Building Gate 14, Barker Street University of New South Wales, NSW 2052

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study will examine whether a correlation exists between contamination of contact lens cases with Stenotrophomonas maltophilia and CIEs, when contact lenses and worn on a daily wear basis. The hypothesis is case contamination with Stenotrophomonas maltophilia does not correlate with CIEs.
